indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Availability of information on HIV and AIDS spending. - Level of mainstreaming of HIV and gender issues in development policies, programmes and plans - Existence of adequate capacity of umbrella organisations to coordinate HIV responses. - Existence of human resources in the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Existence of evidence to inform sustainable financing mechanisms / options for the HIV response

baseline.comment: - No information on actual spending on HIV and AIDS - Limited mainstreaming of HIV and gender issues in development policies, programmes and plans - Inadequate capacity of umbrella organisations to coordinate HIV responses. - Inadequate capacity of the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Unsustainable financing mechanisms for the HIV response

target.comment: -Information on HIV and AIDS spending availed e.g National AIDS accountability Score card institutionalized - HIV and gender issues mainstreamed in development policies, programmes and plans. Specfically: 1. An HIV committee established in Kampala city authority 2- Increased number of top political and urban leaders committed to the National HIV response 3- Non communicable disease health clubs established among university students 4- Increase in the number of newspaper publications on Non communicable diseases and tobacco control 5- At least 15 women and girls living with and orphaned with HIV supported in 2 districts to regain access to property and land 6- Advocacy for removal of clauses that impact on HIV regression in the HIV Prevention and Management bill 7- Advocacy with law makers and policy makers on the need to manage the impact of the Anti homosexuality Act - Adequate capacity of umbrella organisations in place to coordinate HIV responses. e.g Supporting Uganda AIDS Commission to engender the National HIV Strategic Plan and the Global fund process -Availability of Human resources in the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Evidence in place to inform sustainable financing mechanisms / options for the HIV response

actual.comment:
-Availability of information on HIV and AIDS spending. National Aids accountability score card was launched, disseminated and institutionalized in 7 districts, as a result there is increased accountability of health services in certain health centers like Mwiizi health center 4 where the government vehicle was brought back due to the community demand . -HIV and gender issues have been to some extent mainstreamed in development policies, programmes and plans. Specifically: 1- An HIV committee was institutionalized at Kampala City authority which has facilitated the organization of the elimination of mother to child transmission campaign in Kampala district 2- Increased commitment of political leaders in addressing the HIV response which has contributed to decline in the number of new infections from 140,000 to 120,000 and also lead to the reduction mother to child transmission rates from 21000 to 8000 new infections ( Country Progress report) 3- Urban leaders currently integrating gender and HIV in their urban programs and plans as a result there is increased commitment of urban leaders in mobilizing their communities to access HIV prevention, care and treatment services 4 - Two non communicable disease health clubs have been established in Mukono and Kampala University 5 - One way SMS platform has been develop to sensitize the youth about the dangers of smoking and related non communicable diseases. 6- Eleven women and 7 girls living with and affected with HIV have been supported to regain access to their property and land , as a result 2 girls that had dropped out school have bounced back to school.
7- As a result of the gender and HIV integration study conducted last year, gender and HIV training have been conducted for the local government sectors leading to the increase in gender informed budgets and work plans submitted to the ministry of local government; 8.An HIV and the law dialogue was conducted in an effort to sensitize policy makers,

target.comment:
- Availability of information on HIV and AIDS spending. - HIV and gender issues mainstreamed in development policies, programmes and plans of 20 LGs - Existence of adequate capacity of umbrella organisations to coordinate HIV responses. - Existence of human resources in the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Existence of evidence to inform sustainable financing mechanisms / options for the HIV response
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx i. Conduct 1 Urban Leaders AIDS Forum ii.Review 3 AMICAAL policies iii.240 students sensitized and capacities built to do peer education on HIV and NCDs prevention iv. 1 documentary for TV mentions for 2 months about health service delivery from rural health centres v.Provide legal aid to 60 clients

actual.comment: - Information on HIV and AIDS spending in place. - HIV and gender issues mainstreamed in development programmes and plans of 25 districts - Adequate capacity of 3 umbrella organizations(UNASO/AIDs commission/PROBICOU) is in place to coordinate HIV responses. - Existence of human resources in the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Existence of evidence to inform sustainable financing mechanisms / options for the HIV response

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Thematic working group on GHG inventory system and national dialogue platforms and coordination mechanisms established. 2. Number of Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMA) full proposals in place. 3. MRV for GHG inventory systems and NAMAs in place.

baseline.comment: 1. There are no thematic working groups and dialogue platforms on GHG inventory systems in place. 2. There is no systematic Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs) development full proposal yet. 3. There is no MRV for GHG Inventory system and NAMA in place.

target.comment: 1. Thematic Working Group on GHG Inventory established and Sources of available data in key source categories identified. 2. Two NAMA full proposals prepared. 3. MRV systems designed to support implementation and evaluation of NAMAs.

actual.comment: 1. Thematic working groups on Greenhouse Gas inventory created and capacity developed. A study was also completed on institutional and data collecting arrangements that identified the available data in the key sectors. Furthermore a Greenhouse Gas Manual was developed to guide the UNDP facilitated Greenhouse Gas Unit under the Climate Change department to support the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory system. 2. Two Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMA) were developed. One NAMA concept has received funds from GEF to be fully implemented and another NAMA concept to be funded by the Low Emission Capacity Building global unit. 3. Measuring, Reporting and verification (MRV) systems/ framework is still under formulation.

target.comment: 1. Thematic working group on GHG inventory system and national dialogue platforms and coordination mechanisms established. 2. Number of Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMA) full proposals in place. 3. MRV for GHG inventory systems and NAMAs in place.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Uganda Diaspora Information Portal in place 2. Diaspora paper and policy providing policy framework for engaging internally and externally on Diaspora issues developed 3. Institutional arrangements for research and development in diplomacy and strategic studies strengthened. 4. International bonds - Feasibility established and internationalized i.e number of prints&electronic media and websites, increased Diaspora investments 5. Diaspora service department and key missions/desks on Diaspora fully connected.

baseline.comment: 1. Information protocol/system not in place for greater coordination and strategic partnerships with the diaspora i.e No database on expertise and skills of Diaspora in place, No VOIP system in place. 2. No Diaspora Policy and paper in place 3. No Government recognized specialized institute in country on diplomacy and strategic studies

target.comment: 1.Diaspora service department and key missions/desks on Diaspora fully connected. Enhanced MoFAs Website/ Information portal/system functional in at least ten missions abroad. 2.A technical Paper/ Historical Assessment Report to be printed and launched. 3. Publish a book : Uganda and the World:

actual.comment: 1.Diaspora service department and key missions/desks on Diaspora fully connected.The enhanced MoFAs Website has greatly improved information accessibility, coordination and strategic partnerships with the Diaspora. Ugandans in the Diaspora can now interact with MoFA officials through the MoFA Social Media network. 2. A technical Paper to highlight issues from the draft Diaspora Policy was done. And the issues were incorporated in the draft policy which is before cabinet for consideration. 3. The Book Uganda and the World: Half a Century of Foreign Policy 1962-2012 informs people about Ugandas ever growing relationship with the rest of the World and its peacefulness, development and economic potential

target.comment:
1. Uganda Diaspora Information Portal in place Updated website/documentary in place
2.Diaspora paper and policy providing policy framework for engaging internally and externally on Diaspora issues developed. Support developed of drafting 2 foreign policy bills.
3. Institutional arrangements for research and development in diplomacy and strategic studies strengthened. A diplomatic institute put in place. 4. International bonds - Feasibility established and internationalized i.e number of prints&electronic media and websites, increased Diaspora investments 5. Diaspora service department and key missions/desks on Diaspora fully connected.

actual.comment:
1. Uganda Diaspora Information Portal in place. There is a MOFA Updated website/documentary in place. A video documentary for Ugandans in the Diaspora has been prepared and has inspired Ugandans in diaspora to come and invest back at home in the areas of education, hotel and hospitality, health as well as manufacturing and trade. They are now aware of government programmes like National Registration of IDs
2.Diaspora paper and policy providing policy framework for engaging internally and externally on Diaspora issues developed. The process of drafting of the two bills Foreign Service bill and Uganda Institute for Diplomacy and International Affairs bills commenced. These two bills are critical because they will not only help build capacity of our Foreign Service but impact on Ugandas relations with the rest of the world
3. Institutional arrangements for research and development in diplomacy and strategic studies strengthened. From the roundtable workshop with donors, China pledged to construct the Institute, while South Korea and Norway promised to help at a later stage with capacity building programmes.
4. International bonds - Feasibility established and internationalized
5. Diaspora service department and key missions/desks on Diaspora fully connected.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
i.Revised harmonised regulatory framework for LG planning and budgeting in place. ii. Harmonised Acts in place (i.e Local Government Act, NPA Act and Budget Act)
iii.Selected districts and municipalities equipped with ICT to carry out effective planning and budgeting.
iv. Number of LGs trained on PPP policy and guidelines and are utilizing PPP approach in LG service delivery.

baseline.comment:
i.Weak and inconsistent legal, regulatory and coordination framework for service delivery i.e. Inconsistencies in mechanism for creation of districts and gaps in staffing structure.
ii.Legal, regulatory and coordination frameworks i.e. LG Act, NPA Act and budget Act are not harmonised for effective service delivery.
iii.Inadequate capacity (soft and hard ware) by LGs to deliver services.
iv.Public Private Partnership framework, not available at the LG level to inform service delivery.

target.comment:
i. Revised harmonised Local Government Planning and budgeting guidelines and training manual completed. ii.Disseminate and train 20 Local Governments on Public Private Policy Guidelines
iii.Equip 33 districts and 9 newly created municipalities with ICT equipments (GPSs) and have officers trained on its use.

actual.comment: i. The revised harmonised Local Government (LGs)Planning and Budgeting Guidelines and Training manual Have been completed and are in place, being used by all Local Governments. ii. Dissemination and training of 24 Local Governments on Public Private Policy Guidelines against the target of 20 Local governments (LGs) have been completed. This has led to identification of additional sources of funding for example partnering with the private sector to provide health and education services in Local Governments other than relying on Central Government transfers and conditional grants. iii. Forty two Local governments (33 districts and 9) newly created municipalities were equipped with ICT equipment (GPSs) and have officers trained on its use.

target.comment:
i.Revised harmonised regulatory framework for LG planning and budgeting in place. ii. Harmonised Acts in place (i.e Local Government Act, NPA Act and Budget Act)
iii.Selected districts and municipalities equipped with ICT to carry out effective planning and budgeting.
iv. 20 LGs trained on PPP policy and guidelines and are utilizing PPP approach in LG service delivery.

actual.comment:
I. Revised harmonized regulatory framework for LG planning and budgeting in place. 27 Generic Training Materials were revised to address policy and structural changes such as local economic development, community driven development, climate change, private sector financing, peace building, target surpassed
ii. Harmonized Acts in place
iii. 15 Selected districts and municipalities equipped with ICT to carry out effective planning and budgeting. Global Positioning Systems equipment installed and LG officers trained
iv. 24 LGs acquired PPP Policy framework and target surpassed.LG Women Leadership forum established in 8 LGs, target surpassed.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. No. of contracts between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. No. of Memorandum of understanding signed 3. No. of MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. No of tourism support institutions strengthened

baseline.comment: Tourism has a high potential for income generation and has been identified as one of the priority sectors by Government. However, the tourism sector is still underdeveloped, with a weak policy and regulatory framework; limited access to markets; limited product scope, weak business and technical skills; weak value chains. The following was the project baseline status: 1. Zero contracts between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. Zero Memorandum of understanding signed 3. Zero MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. Zero tourism support institutions strengthened

target.comment:
Target 1
30 business linkages in selected tourism product value chains developed and operationalised
Target 2
6 Innovative Pro-poor Tourism Business Models developed and operationalised
Target 3
Capacity of 30 MSMEs in selected tourism product value chains strengthened to increase productivity and competitiveness
Target 4
Capacity of three selected Tourism Business Support Associations and institutions strengthened in service delivery and membership development.

actual.comment:
Target 1
As at end of June, 2014, 17 business linkages in selected tourism product value chains had been established; and 10 letters of establishment signed.
Target 2
7 case studies to elaborate the pro-poor, innovative tourism business models into the defined categories and 6 Tourism Business Models have been prepared. Further, the business development needs of the entities in the models have been identified. This will support the development of interventions to strengthen the pro-poor, innovative tourism business models.
Target 3
18 MSMEs strengthened. Specifically:
- 73 members of executive committees from 6 tourism Business Support Associations (BSAs) were emparted with knowledge and skills in Strategic Planning and Business Management of Tourism business associations and institutions
- 94 members of executive committees from 6 tourism BSAs were emparted with knowledge and skills in growing membership bases, improving customer care and service; and management of consumer markets
- 32 members of executive committees of 6 tourism BSAs were emparted with knowledge and skills in lobbying and advocacy
Target 4
Not yet started.

target.comment: 1. 12 contracts/business linkages between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. 10 Memorandum of understanding signed 3. 15 MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. 3 tourism support institutions strengthened

actual.comment:
1. 12 business linkages between key market off-takers and MSMEs were strengthened, which has resulted in increased access to markets by the small enterprises (MSMEs), as well as growth of their businesses.
2. 15 Memorandum of understanding signed 3. 15 MSME's in tourism strengthened through extensive trainings 4. Overall five (three tourism business support associations and two tourism support institutions) was strengthened in areas of quality assurance, research and evidence-based planning; development and implementation of sustainable marketing and branding strategies as well as development of their 5 year Strategic Plans

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. No. of contracts(business linkages) between micro and mall enterprises (MSMEs) and large enterprises (market off-takers) signed and operational
2. No. of MSME's accessing and utilizing agricultural extension services, financial services, technology, market information
3. No. of small holder producers and other MSMEs engaged in Rice, Cassava and Beans production in the selected agro-ecological zones, accessing agricultural extension and business development services .
4. No. of Memorandum of Understanding (MOUs) signed for MSMEs

baseline.comment: Agriculture contributes up to 23.6% of GDP while employing 83% of women (who contribute to 70-75% of agricultural production), and 71% of the men. More than 80% of the total agricultural output is produced through small-holder farms. However, the sector faces significant challenges - including low production volumes and inconsistent levels of supply, inadequate extension and business support services, limited market access and weak market chains.

target.comment:
Target 1
20 business linkages in Rice, Cassava and Beans Value Chains established
Target 2
13 business supoort associations (BSAs) strengthened
Target 3
5 pro-poor business models in agriculture sector designed and implemented
Target 4
200 MSMEs facilitated access to productive assets

actual.comment:
Target 1
(50) MoUs were signed between market off-takers and MSMEs. Among them, (31) have moved on to the next step in signing supply contracts.
Target 2
(13) business support associations have been receiving capacity building support including, strategic planning, governance, group formation, and production and marketing management.
Target 3
(10) pro-poor business models were developed and among them, (4) models were approved by the Technical Advisory Committee and ready for implementation.
Target 4
(600) MSMEs have been facilitated to access productive assets such as appropriate technologies, quality inputs, financial services, and market information.

target.comment: 1) 20 business linkages operationalized 2) 6 exchange visits conducted 3) 1 Innovative pro-poor business operationalized 4) 200 MSMEs facilitated access to productive assets

actual.comment: 1) 33 business linkages operationalized 2) 6 exchange visits conducted 3) 1 Innovative pro-poor business operationalized 4) More than 600 MSMEs accessing productive assets

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Diagnostic study report on the review of the National Environment Management Policy (NEMP), related policies, laws and strategies in place. 2. Draft Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) sectoral guidelines for the energy, agriculture and, mining in place. 3. Strategy for management of Electronic waste in place. 4. Draft national biomass energy strategy in place. 5. Capacity building programme in place 5.1 National institutional capacity needs assessment report for Climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management. 5.2 Training manual for climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management.

baseline.comment: 1. The National Environment Management Policy (1994) is in place but not reviewed or updated to cater for emerging environmental challenges. 2. The National Environmental Impact Assessment Regulations are in place but no EIA sectoral guidelines (for agriculture, mining, energy and other key sectors). 3. There is an electronic waste management policy but no strategy for management of electronic waste in place. 4. No national biomass energy strategy in place. 5.1 There is a National Disaster Preparedness and Management Policy and platform in place but there is an inadequate capacity for coordination of Climate risk management. 5.2 Most relevant government officials are inadequately skilled in climate risk management.

target.comment: 1. Draft National Environment Management Framework Policy in place. State of Environment Report in place. 2. Final Environment Impact Assessment guidelines for Agriculture, Mining, Energy and Fisheries sectors in place. Environment Natural Resources (ENR) gender strategy in place. Draft Wetlands Atlas in place. Baseline data sets for ENR Performance Measurement Framework in place. Draft Environment and natural resources gender strategy produced. ENR data collection tool in place. 3. Electronic waste strategy in place. 4. Biomass Energy Strategy in place. 5. Training manual on Climate Risk Management in place. Coordination Strategy for Climate Risk Management in place

actual.comment: 1. A final draft National state of environment report (NSOER) in place. 2. A final Environment Impact Assessment guidelines for Agriculture, Mining, Energy and Fisheries sectors in place; Draft National Wetlands Atlas in place. Draft Performance Measurement Framework (PMF) data collection tool in place and; Draft ENR gender strategy produced. 3. Electronic waste strategy in place. 4. Final Biomass Energy Strategy in place and launched. 5. Training manual on Climate Risk Management in place.

target.comment:
1. National Environment Management Policy (NEMP), related policies, laws and strategies in place. e.g Draft monitoring, implementation framework and communication facility for the draft National Environment Management Policy (NEMP); Draft Wetlands Atlas in place.
2. Some Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) sectoral guidelines for the energy, agriculture and, mining are in place and Electronic waste management guidelines development is under development
3. Strategy for management of Electronic waste in place. 4. National biomass energy strategy in place. 5. Capacity building programme in place 5.1 National institutional capacity needs assessment report for Climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management. 5.2 Training manual for climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management.

actual.comment:
1. National Environment Management Policy (NEMP), related policies, laws and strategies in place. including a draft monitoring, implementation framework and communication facility for the draft National Environment Management Policy (NEMP) and a draft Wetlands Atlas.
2. Draft Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) sectoral guidelines for the energy, agriculture and, mining in place including Electronic waste management guidelines 3. Strategy for management of Electronic waste in place. 4. Draft national biomass energy strategy in place. 5. Capacity building programme in place

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Demonstration nurseries for trial and propagation of selected threatened tree species in place. 2. Acreage of degraded sites planted with threatened tree species 3. Number of target communities supported to develop eco-tourism strategies. 4. Number of community based organizations identified to pilot sustainable land management best practices. 5. Acreage of fragile environments/ dry lands planted with recommended trees. 6. Number institutional and household biogas units constructed. 7. Quantity of Renewable Energy Technologies (RET) produced/ adopted. 8. Number of innovative Climate change adaptation initiatives established

baseline.comment: 1. Zero or No demonstration nurseries for threatened tree species in biodiversity hot spots. 2. Fragile environments are degraded and bare. 3. No target communities supported to develop eco-tourism strategies. Some areas have eco-tourism potential but lack innovative products for ecotourism. 4. Communities not implementing SLM best practices. 5. Fragile and dry lands are bare with no recommended trees. 6. Low adoption of alternative energy technologies such as no institutional and household biogas units. 7. There are no and/or inadequate quantities of RET produced/ adopted within the target communities. 8. Zero or no innovative climate change adaptation initiatives in target communities.

target.comment: 1. Demonstration nurseries for at least four (4) species of conservation concern in place 2. 1000ha in both institutions and degraded sites planted with both tree species of conservation concern and non-conservation concern 3. At least three (3) community management strategies and plans for ecotourism management in place 4. At least three (3) community based Catchment management action plans implementing SLM interventions. 5. 1000ha of degraded fragile landscapes restored through planting of recommended trees 6. At least 6 biogas units constructed. 7. At least three efficient biomass energy technologies tested and four community groups plus two institutions using RET 8. Sub-surface rain water harvesting technologies exist in 4 target districts

actual.comment: 1. Two demonstration nurseries for trial and propagation of selected threatened tree species established including one in Kasese District and another in Mitooma Districts. 2. A total of 148 Ha of degraded sites planted with threatened tree species. These included a total of 75 Ha of degraded sites in Kasese namely Mobuku forest reserve, Bugoye and Kitholu sub counties where a total of 35,000 seedlings were planted, and a total of 50 Ha in Mitooma District including 42 Ha where 19000 seedlings were planted on the bare hills of Katenge, Kabira Primary School and Bubare Church of Uganda and the 8 Ha in Kiryabwanga sub country where about 8000 seedlings were planted. 3. Two Community Based Organizations supported under the Small Grants Scheme to promote eco-tourism initiatives including one to construct a viewing platform at the escarpment and another to make paper from elephant dung both in Rubirizi Districts near Queen Elizabeth National Park. 4. Nineteen Community Based Organizations Catchment management action plans in place/ under the Small Grants Scheme and are practicing sustainable land management best practices through tree planting, digging of trenches across the steep slopes in Districts of Kasese, Mitooma, Rubirizi, Bududa and Manafwa Districts. For instance, in Bududa District along the slopes of Mountain Elgon, 39.5 km of trenches have been constructed and use of mulch & cow dung manure adopted. 5. One hundred and twenty four Hectares of fragile and dry lands planted with recommended trees including 105 Ha with indigenous species and 19 Ha with exotic species. 6. Two institutional biogas units were constructed including one in Butiru Secondary School in Manafwa District and one in Karambi Secondary School in Kasese District. 10 household biogas units were constructed including 4 in Manafwa, 2 in Isingiro Districts and another 4 household biogas units in Bududa. 7. One hundred and eighty mud cook stoves were constructed and distributed by a total of 1

target.comment:
1. 2 Demonstration nurseries/projects for trial and propagation . 2. 200 Acreage of degraded sites planted with threatened tree species 3. Two target communities supported to develop eco-tourism strategies. 4. Two community based organizations identified to pilot sustainable land management best practices. 5. 100 Acreage of fragile environments/ dry lands planted with recommended trees. 6. Two institutional and household biogas units constructed. 7. 10 Quantity of Renewable Energy Technologies (RET) produced/ adopted. 8. 20 innovative Climate change adaptation initiatives established
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx 1. 1000ha in both institutions and degraded sites planted with both tree species of conservation concern and non conservation concern as well as 1000ha of degraded landscapes restored. 2. At least six efficient biomass energy technologies tested in four Districts plus one institutions using Renewable Energy Technologies (RET). 3. At least three (3) community groups promoting climate resilient development strategies.

actual.comment:
1. Four demonstration nurseries/projects for trial and propagation in place.There was establishment of demonstration apiaries in the districts of Kasese (1) and Rubirizi (1). In addition, two CFM groups in the districts of Kasese and Rubirizi, that is, MIFA and BUECA respectively were trained on modern Beekeeping.
2. A total of 584.6 Ha were planted with trees and stabilized with vegetation cover under small grants. A total of 405.6ha were planted under small grants [in Kasese district, 124ha in Kitholhu Sub-County, 55.8ha in Mobuku forest reserve plus 7ha on private land; and in Mitooma district, bare hills of Katenga (0.8ha), Kabira (2ha), Kiyanga (1ha), Kashenshero (3ha) and Kanyabwanga (0.5ha) plus Mitooma town council (1ha)].
3. More than eight (8) communities were supported to promote climate development strategies ranging from sub surface water harvesting technologies, water harvesting tanks, planting of coffee seedlings and Mushroom growing.
4. Two community based organizations identified to pilot sustainable land management best practices.
5. A total of 179ha of fragile ecosystems were stabilized with vegetation cover under small grants throughout the districts of Bududa, Rubirizi, Mitooma and Kasese districts. In addition, a total of 88.5km of trench and water bands were constructed and vegetation cover to stabilize them planted (Bududa district 60.5km, Mitooma district 2km and Kasese district 26km).
6. Two institutional biogas facilities constructed in the schools of Karambi and Butiru in Kasese and Manafwa districts respectively
7. 17 Renewable Energy Technologies were established including 15 domestic biogas units including eight (8) in Manafwa district by a CBO, Youth ending hunger; six (6) in Bududa district by Namasho women group; one (1) in Isingiro district by Conservation Effort for Community Development (CECOD) were constructed. In addition, six (6) domestic biogas units were constructed through two contractors four in Manafwa distr

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
i. Number of individuals supported with knowledge and skills for evidence-based analytical research
ii. Procedures and institutional mechanism to plan and produce evidence-based analytical research in place
iii. No. of Evidence Based Studies completed to inform policy formulation and implementation
iv. No. of Evidence Based Studies disseminated to inform policy formulation and implementation

baseline.comment:
Insufficient individual, organization and institutional capacities exist for research at EDPR
Policy Makers and the general public not fully utilizing evidence based analytical studies to inform decision making and policy formulation and implementation processes
Limited and/or no dissemination of evidence-based analytical studies to policy makers and engagement of general public in research and policy making processes

target.comment:
i.Twenty (20) individuals from government and national research community equipped with knowledge and skills for evidence-based analytical research
ii. One (1) set of research procedures and institutional mechanisms to plan, produce and manage evidence-based analytical research in place that inform government strategic policy making priorities iii. Two (2) Evidence Based Studies completed to inform policy formulation and implementation

actual.comment:
(1) In partnership with UN-DESA,30 individuals from Government of Uganda were trained in mainstreaming sustainable development in national development strategies through Sustainable Development Modeling (SDM). The SDM integrates two models that is the Marquette for MDGs Simulations model (MAMS) that was used in the preparation of the Uganda Millennium Development Goal (MDG) report 2013 and the Osymoses model that analyses energy efficiency,
(2) A set of research procedures and institutional mechanisms to plan, produce and manage evidence-based analytical research is in place. This informs government strategic policy making priorities. Specifically, Government of Uganda adopted the MDG report 2013 and was used in the preparation of the budget for the F/Y 2014/2015.
(3) One evidence Based Study was completed and informed policy formulation and implementation. The project has also supported the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development (MFPED) in the preparation of the bi-annual Poverty Status Report launched in September 2014.

target.comment:
i. At least 18 offfcers trained in Macro modelling and microeconomic analytical skills in key government ministries dealing in energy, land, water, environment and agriculture institutionalised by 2015
ii. Procedures and institutional mechanism to plan and produce evidence-based analytical research in place
iii. Four Evidence Based Studies completed to inform policy formulation and implementation
iv. Four Evidence Based Studies disseminated to inform policy formulation and implementation

actual.comment:
The following results have been achieved as of May 2015
i. 21 individuals supported with knowledge and skills for evidence-based analytical research
ii. Procedures and institutional mechanism to plan and produce evidence-based analytical research in place
iii. Four Evidence Based Studies completed to inform policy formulation and implementation
iv. Four Evidence Based Studies disseminated to inform policy formulation and implementation

target.comment: a-20 institutions integrate environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans; -Established institutions and processes for early warning, disaster and climate modelling, assessments and emergency/recovery coordination. - Conduct nationwide comprehensive hazard, risk, and Vulnerability mapping/profiling - Pilot of innovative approaches on Disaster and climate risk and resilience-building - Improved preparedness level and response to early recovery needs. - Improved capacities and harmonized tools/approaches for more efficient delivery of Disaster /Climate Risk Management initiatives - capacity at national and sub national levels in place to manage disaster and climate risk management

actual.comment: a- 25 institutions integrated environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans. Specifically there is the following: -Existence of established and operationalized institutions and process for early warning, disaster and climate modelling, assessments and emergency/recovery coordination. - Nationwide comprehensive hazard, risk, and Vulnerability mapping/profiling completed - Innovative approaches on Disaster and climate risk and resilience-building piloted - Existence of an institution for Improved preparedness level and response to early recovery needs. - Harmonized tools/approaches in place for more efficient delivery of Disaster /Climate Risk Management initiatives - Capacity at national and sub national levels to manage disaster and climate risk management in place

target.comment: a - 50 institutions integrating environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans; (Disaggregated by level i.e National/Local government - Develop the Strategic Programmes and Investment Framework document - Strengthen co-ordination of DRR activities through the conduct and facilitation of regular National Platform for DRR meetings. -Operationalize and roll out the Early Warning systems in targeted districts in Teso, Acholi and West Nile sub regions. - Conduct national Hazard Risk and Vulnerability assessment for targeted districts and publish their hazard profiles. - Commemorate the observance of special days/events including the International day for DRR.

actual.comment:

-Strategic Programmes and Investment Framework document in place; - Well Co-ordinated DRR activities through regular National Platform for DRR meetings. - Strengthened national DRR institutions, enhanced sectoral coordination and DRR main-streamed into national and sector-specific development policies and programmes - Evidence base for DRR generated and post-disaster recovery strengthened - Enhanced community resilience to disasters - Enhanced capacity for comprehensive disaster risk reduction

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. National Consultative Forum (NCF) fully operational with key capacities to deliver on constitutional mandate
2.Existence of legislation associated with electoral processes and multiparty political dispensation
3. Operational Non-state dialogue platform in place i.e policy and governance settlements facilitated by the National Elders Forum (NEF) and Operational framework for NEF finalized
4. Policy and governance settlements facilitated by Non-structures (NEF and in close conjunction with NCF and IRCU)
5. Regional peace and conflict transformation forums in place- led dialogue and internal mediation in diffusing conflict triggers at regional levels
6. Existence of Independent and impartial secretariat for the operations of the NEF/NCF/IRCU.

baseline.comment:
1. Forum for dialogue with constitutional mandate exists with limited information on capacity needs of forum
2. Political reform dialogue towards strengthening multiparty political dispensation within NCF not yet fully developed. Core Electoral reform proposals already developed/identified. NCF support for approval through next steps of legislative processes needed.
3. Non-state dialogue platform not fully operationalized
4. Limited non-state structures that can facilitate dialogue and consensus building
5. Regional level peace-building infrastructure is weak and limited in capacity
6. Independent and impartial secretariat for the operations of the NEF is not in existence.

target.comment:
1. National Consultative Forum (NCF) fully operational with key capacities to deliver on constitutional mandate
2. Existence of legislation associated with electoral processes and multiparty political dispensation finalized
3. Operational Non-state dialogue platform in place i.e policy and governance settlements facilitated by the NEF Operational framework for National Elders Forum (NEF) finalized 4. Policy and governance settlements are facilitated by Non-structures 5.Regional peace and conflict transformation forums in place- led dialogue and internal mediation in diffusing conflict triggers at regional levels 6. Independent and impartial secretariat for the operations of the NEF/NCF/IRCU in place

actual.comment:
1. National Consultative Forum (NCF) fully operational with key capacities to deliver on constitutional mandate
2. Existence of legislation associated with electoral processes and multiparty political dispensation finalized
3. Operational Non-state dialogue platform in place i.e policy and governance settlements facilitated by the NEF Operational framework for National Elders Forum (NEF) finalized 4. Policy and governance settlements are facilitated by Non-structures (NEF and in close conjunction with NCF and Inter religious Council Of Uganda (IRCU) 5. Regional peace and conflict transformation forums in place- led dialogue and internal mediation in diffusing conflict triggers at regional levels 6.Existence of Independent and impartial secretariat for the operations of the NEF/NCF/IRCU.

target.comment:
Output 1 1. National Consultative Forum (NCF) fully operational with key capacities to deliver on constitutional mandate
2. Existence of legislation associated with electoral processes and multiparty political dispensation
3. Operational Non-state dialogue platform in place. A functional National Elders Forum is in place
4. Policy and governance reform dialogue processes in partnership with NCF and IRCU facilitated and finalized. Capacity of Women in Faith Network to coordinate religious action for women's role in peace-building strengthened
5. Four regional peace and conflict transformation forums established Early warning tool to monitor developments that impact peace and stability integrated Peace and conflict transformation Forums to facilitate dialogue interventions identified Services of a full time focal point for managing the early warning tool within IRCU recruited
6. fully functional secretariat to support NEF operations and project management in place

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Existence of a new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) 2. Number of selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced i.e.
3. Existence of Spatial mapping report and associated maps 4. Existence of NDPII incorrporating an M&E framework.

baseline.comment:
1. No new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) . Only NDPI exists; 2. No NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced yet.
3. No existence of Spatial mapping report and associated maps 4. None existence of NDPII incorporating an M&E framework.

target.comment:
1. A new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) in place 2. Five selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced
3. Spatial mapping report and associated maps in place 4. Existence of NDPII incorporating an M&E framework.

actual.comment:
1. A New macroeconomic framework for NDP-II was developed 2. Six selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced i.e. a. NDP-II cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Democratic governance and the NDP-II completed b. NDP-II cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Sustainability, environmental management and the NDP-II completed c. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Mainstreaming Non-State Actors participation in the NDP completed d. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of youth in the NDP completed e. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of agriculture and land main streaming in the NDP completed f. NDP-II LG Issues papers completed. 4. Spatial mapping report and associated maps completed 5. NDPII completed incorporating an M&E framework
1.1 Macro framework draft has been finalized and will be presented to cabinet and Parliament for review and approval. 1.2 The Core macro team from NPA was trained in development strategies through Sustainable Development Modeling (SDM). The SDM integrates two models that is the Marquette for MDGs Simulations model that was used in the preparation of the Uganda MDG report 2013 and the Osymoses model that analyses energy efficiency, as well as other enabling factors such as land, agriculture and the environment which will come in handy given the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals.

target.comment: 1. A New macroeconomic framework for NDP-II in place which also provides a basis for technical Backstopping of Local Gorvenments and Municipalities in developing their development plans as well as Quality Assurance of Local Government Development Plans 2. Three Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced

actual.comment:
1. A New macroeconomic framework for NDP-II in place where 49 local governments were support to have quality assured development plans. Over 30 Local Governments had their capacity built on the use of the LG development planning guidelines and supported them in developing their plans.
2. 10 Cross-cutting Theme Papers/reports were produced that informed policy direction. They include the MDG report/Human Development report,the Re-engineering cooperatives report, African Economic Outlook Report etc

result.title: Objective
result.description: The Biodiversity of the Kidepo Critical Landscape in North Eastern Uganda is protected from existing and emerging threats

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Ecological stability of entire landscape is increased, biodiversity is less threatened, and habitats are secured;

baseline.comment: Landscape level approaches will not be taken up to the extent that the opportunity allows; risks from Climate change will impact the buffer zones but also PAs themselves, with net loss to biodiversity and to incomes.

target.comment: Effective Terrestrial protected area coverage increased from a baseline of Increased coverage of PA by 95,600 ha over a baseline of 240,075 ha. and designation of buffer zones to conserve dry season refugia for wildlife (227,389 Hectares).

actual.comment: Still early to report on the development objective

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Karenga Community Wildlife Area (CWA) will have the necessary operational and governance capacity built by EoP to be gazetted to full NP status.

baseline.comment: The existing baseline is centred on KVNP as the core area where wildlife are able to peacefully habitat; refugia are limited and insecure, corridors, like Karenga, are under threat.

target.comment: Increased coverage of PA by 95,600 Ha over a baseline of 240,075 Ha. and strengthened integrity of buffer zones to conserve dry season Refugia for wildlife (227,389 Ha).

actual.comment: As a first step towards strengthening management of Karenga community wildlife area, the local leadership and community members were mobilized and sensitized on the importance of the wildlife area and opportunities for ecotourism.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Poaching levels will have decreased.

baseline.comment: Enforcement in the Kidepo Critical Landscape is currently too weak to deal with armed poachers from politically unstable South Sudan, and poaching is a growing problem.

target.comment: Reduced poaching pressures over an area of 428,311 ha comprising seven PAs (one NP, six CFRs) and a community wildlife management area, verified by 25% greater wildlife abundance over the course of the year by EoP.

actual.comment: No progress this year.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: METT scores are improved in the target PAs: Kidepo Valley NP, Nyangea, Morungole, Zulia, Timu, Lwala and Rom CFR.

baseline.comment: Baseline METT scores as follows: Kidepo Valley 65%; Nyangea- 58%; Lwala - 45%, Timu 53%, Morungole 42%; Zulia 53% and Rom 40%. Average score: 52%.

target.comment: Management Effectiveness Score for Kidepo Critical Landscape PA cluster (KVNP), Nyangea-Napore, Morungole, Zulia, Timu, Lwala and Rom CFRs); increased over the baseline score by at least 40%.

actual.comment: Implementation of activities still on-going and data will be generated as implementation goes on to provide a basis for analysis.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Key indicator species in the Kidepo Critical Landscape PA cluster show measurable increase in numbers.

baseline.comment: Elephant population in 2012 was 502; zebra: 75; buffalo: 3,990; these are relatively depleted numbers relative to the carrying capacity of the landscape.

target.comment: Key indicator species (elephants, zebra, buffalo) in the Kidepo Critical Landscape PA cluster show measurable increase in numbers of 25% by EoP.

actual.comment: Inventory undertaken. Analysis of data on-going.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Deforestation, community wildlife agreements.

baseline.comment: Cooperation between UWA and NFA is relatively limited; cooperation between different districts is minimal, especially in terms of managing wildlife and forest resources.

target.comment: A working model for integrating management of PAs and wider production landscapes is piloted and adopted in six districts in North Eastern Uganda (Kitgum, Kaabong, Agago, Otuke, Abim and Kotido) and secures wildlife corridors and dispersal areas covering approximately 227,389 ha - resulting in reduced deforestation of shea by 25 %.

actual.comment: Consultations with six pilot districts and members of parliament initiated. The importance of landscape approach to management of Kidepo National Park and migratory route including Shea belt dispersal area in the process of being mapped out.

target.comment:
Awareness and enforcement activities to reduce cutting of Shea butter trees for charcoal production on-going and there is observed reduction in cutting of the trees
UWA carries our regular monitoring to detect illegal activities such as poaching. Statistics on the trends of poaching to be analyzed to assess progress towards the target of 40%.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Common management approaches to habitat conservation.

baseline.comment: There are no management plans for PA buffer zones, as a result there lacks a coordinated response to wildlife and habitat conservation in the Kidepo Critical Landscape.

target.comment: PA buffer zone under approved district management plans in six districts (Kitgum, Kaabong, Agago, Otuke, Abim and Kotido) incorporating BD considerations.

actual.comment: No progress this year but planned for next year.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Six district governments (Kitgum, Kaabong, Agago, Otuke, Abim and Kotido) are collaborating on shared management issues.

baseline.comment: No mechanism is presently in place for joint management planning for natural resource use by local governments in the critical landscape.

target.comment: District governments in six districts cooperate effectively to regulate and plan natural resource use over 227,389 Ha of the critical landscape, resulting in a landscape level coordination mechanism that enshrines biodiversity conservation by mandate.

actual.comment: Inter-district coordination mechanism on enforcement and awareness in place and operational involving district political and technical staff. It is coordinated by the Resident District Commissioner of Otuke district for the 4 shea butter tree oilt districts of Kitgum, Agago, Otuke and Abim.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthening management effectiveness of the Kidepo Critical Landscape PA cluster

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Existence of functional and operational management structure in Kidepo PA and CFRs systems

baseline.comment: The Kidepo Cluster P.A.s, CFRs and Karenga lack operational capacity (human resources and equipment) to manage secure PA operations such as fires, control poaching and monitoring.

target.comment: Establish a security and enforcement system with a platform for information sharing and intelligence gathering among parks and other institutions; with databases that will be continuously updated. Includes provision of surveillance equipment, ranger uniforms, fire management tools.

actual.comment: As a first step towards strengthening management effectiveness in the Kidepo Critical Landscape PA cluster, sensitization meetings with the local leadership including Area Members of Parliament in the project area were conducted and their buy-in on biodiversity conservation secured.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of security and enforcement systems, platforms for information sharing and intelligence gathering in the PA cluster

baseline.comment: There is no security and enforcement system as well as a platform for information sharing and intelligence gathering in the PA cluster

target.comment: At least one security and enforcement system, one platform for information sharing and one intelligence gathering mechanism established.

actual.comment: To boost the security enforcement mechanisms of the PA cluster, equipment (GPS, radio motor rollers, binoculars, water bottles, knives, first aid kits) for Ranger use during enforcement patrols procured.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of sustainable financing plans for the PA cluster

baseline.comment: There are no sustainable financing plans for the PA cluster

target.comment: At least two sustainable financing plans developed

actual.comment: No progress but planned for next year

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: No. of UWA and NFA rangers, district government staff, NFA and UWA administrative staff trained.

baseline.comment: UWA and NFA rangers, District government staff, UWA and NFA admin staff are inadequately trained in conflict resolution, policing, tourism customer care, fire management and law enforcement

target.comment: 120 UWA and NFA rangers, 12 district government staff, 30 NFA staff and UWA administration staff including at least 30% women.

actual.comment: To improve on UWA's capacity in terms of numbers to monitor wildlife and habitats plus handling human/wildlife conflict, community wildlife scouts were trained on simple animal and habitat data collection methods.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Integrating PA Management in the Wider Landscape

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Sustainable use options (a) Shea and (b) wildlife species that are regulated for sport hunting are implemented and the data is available for operational use.

baseline.comment: No data available for sustainable use options for Shea tree harvesting and wildlife hunting: as a result there is unsustainable use of key species.

target.comment: Operational updated data in place and Sustainable use options for Shea tree resources and wildlife established and implemented.

actual.comment: To enable determination of sustainable use options for shea tree resources and wildlife, Inventory of shea butter trees and resources as well as animal counts in Karenga Community Wildlife Area were conducted to provide data on status of both shea butter trees and resources including key animal species.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Biodiversity management is factored into decision-making governing land use management in District Development Plans.

baseline.comment: Management activities are carried out on NP, CFR district and community levels but with a lack of a landscape level coordination mechanism.

target.comment: Mechanisms (landscape level coordinated management plans and institutional governance systems) for enhancing sustainable management of Kidepo critical landscape promoted, with landscape management plan in place and enforced.

actual.comment: No progress but planned for next year.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: District governments in six districts of Kitgum, Kaabong, Agago, Otuke, Abim and Kotido have proven capacity for managing natural resources sustainably.

baseline.comment: District Governments lack the competence and staff skills to monitor and enforce laws. As a result there is a lack of understanding of the situation vis--vis sustainable hunting and Shea utilization, leading to habitat degradation.

target.comment: Local Governments have the competence and staff skills to monitor and enforce laws on sustainable hunting and sustainable use of Shea tree in target districts, measured by a 40% increase in scores in capacity development scorecard.

actual.comment: In order to improve on the competence and staff skills of local governments, enforcement officers from one district (Otuke) were trained during a two days workshop on enforcement.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: National export strategy for shea products in place; 25% increase in sales; an operational market information centre for shea products; Certified products in marketplace

baseline.comment: The Shea nut / butter market is currently not yielding sufficient returns to producers to justify the conservation of Shea: average yields are 122.5 kg/household/year and average prices for oil 2,500/+ UGX per litre

target.comment: Measures to improve market access for Shea products in place, and employment and income generation among rural women in the pilot area increased through access to markets, leading to a 30% rise in the value of shea products and a 25% increase in sales from start of project

actual.comment: No progress this year but planned for next year

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Existence of inter-district coordination body in place and functioning, with an M & E Plan

baseline.comment: There is no District coordination mechanism in place, leading to a lack of coordination over the management of crucial savannah woodland habitats, Shea trees and wildlife

target.comment: A District coordination mechanism in place in the project target area (six districts) to ensure that biodiversity management in National Parks, Central forest reserves and wildlife migration corridors and dispersal areas is factored into integrated decision-making governing land use management.

actual.comment: As a first step towards formation of a district coordination mechanism for biodiversity management in National Parks, CFRs and wildlife corridors, a district task force on enforcement comprising of Resident District Commissioners (RDCs) and District Environment Officers of Kitgum, Agago, Otuke, Abim, Kaabong and Kotido was formed. Similarly, engagement done with cultural leaders in the six project districts of Abim, Kaabong, Kotido, Otuke, Agago and Kitgum was another starting point for formation of an inter-district coordination mechanism.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Management plan, including zonation plan and regulations in place

baseline.comment: Management plans and regulations critical for wildlife dispersal are presently non-existent in the wider landscape

target.comment: Management plans and regulations on BD-friendly management in blocks identified as critical for wildlife dispersal developed and applied by local governments-resulting in security of buffer zones and wildlife corridors

actual.comment: In order to fasten the management planning process for critical dispersal areas and formulation of regulations for BD-friendly management in identified blocks, incentives in form of community livelihood improvement projects were initiated whereby four community project proposals were approved for funding.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Ordinances and by-laws and being enforced by EoP-

baseline.comment: District ordinances and community by-laws are non-existent for Shea tree harvesting and wildlife hunting

target.comment: District ordinances and community by-laws on the harvest of Shea trees and wildlife hunting reinstated or developed - resulting in 25% reduction in shea tree deforestation and a 50% drop in the use of shea for charcoal

actual.comment: To kick start the development and or reinstatement of district ordinances and community bye laws on harvest of shea butter tree products and wildlife hunting, the District Council and technical staff of Abim including cultural leaders from the six project districts were sensitized.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description:
Outcome 1.1 Existing & ongoing policy, regulatory and institutional work on sustainable charcoal and land tenure security integrated with new biomass energy strategy (BEST) under development
Outcome 1.2 Improved coordination of institutions managing sustainable charcoal production at pilot district level
Outcome 1.3 Improved data collection and monitoring of biomass energy and charcoal production and use (integrated into national database and for use as baseline information in a possible NAMA)
Outcome 1.4 Improved charcoal and biomass guidelines and ordinances at district level
Outcome 1.5 Heightened awareness of new institutional frameworks and ordnances, guidelines and certification schemes at district level

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
(1.1) Biomass Energy Strategy (BEST) developed, validated, approved and in use. National charcoal survey and updated standardized baseline reports completed based on current data
(1.2) Framework for institutional coordination and resource mobilization developed between MEMD, local government authorities and the National Forest Authority to manage charcoal trade at district level
(1.2) Charcoal by-laws including licensing procedures standardized and strengthened
(1.3) Baseline report and functional biomass database established and hosted at MEMD and published in Uganda Bureau of Standards reports
(1.4) Local guidelines and standards for certification schemes developed, adopted and publicized in targeted pilot districts
(1.5) Awareness and educational program on local guidelines and standards completed in all targeted pilot districts
(1.5) Updated guidelines for measuring biomass (CAI & MAI) calculated using the biomass study technical manual. The technical manual will be updated and revised by year 2

baseline.comment:
(1.1) BEST still in design form
(1.2) Biomass energy mandate is distributed across many government agency with no focal point
(1.2) License fees not standardized
(1.3) Current database is uncoordinated, inadequate and unreliable
(1.4) Guidelines and standards non-existent
(1.5) Inadequate and uncoordinated individual /NGO driven and project based programs
(1.5) Biomass measurement guidelines and technical manual are not in use. The technical manual is outdated.

target.comment:
(1.1) Investment mobilized to implement BEST recommendations
(1.1) Standardized baseline accepted by UNFCCC
(1.2) Biomass Unit funded in proportion to revenue collected from the sector & central government budget by year 3.
(1.2) Higher revenue collection by local administration from charcoal by the district by year 2.
(1.3) Updateable baseline and functional database established at MEMD and UBS by end of year 1
(1.4) Guidelines and certification schemes developed and operational by end of year 2.
(1.5) Coordinated awareness campaigns completed in each district by end of year 3
(1.5) Biomass technical manual is updated and available for use by year 2. Updated guidelines developed and in use by year

actual.comment:
(1.1) As part of integrating policies, institutional and regulatory frameworks, the National Biomass Energy Strategy was developed, validated, approved and launched to guide planning and investments in the biomass sector in Uganda
(1.2) Not yet done
(1.3) not yet done, awaiting finalization of the national charcoal survey
(1.4) not yet done
(1.5) In an effort to increase awareness on new institutional frameworks and guidelines for sustainable charcoal management, 500 community beneficiaries (including 150 women) in 4 districts were sensitized on improved charcoal best practices through community based meetings and trainings. Close to half a million people were reached with improved charcoal management messages through 24 live radio talk shows (once per district monthly).

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description:
Outcome 2.1 Low-carbon charcoal production technologies have successfully replaced inefficient systems in targeted pilot districts
Outcome 2.2 Sustainable charcoal recognized as a viable SME in pilot districts by end of project
Outcome 2.3 Carbon finance is integrated into sustainable charcoal practice in targeted areas
Outcome 2.4 Increased incomes for all charcoal cooperatives involved in project
Outcome 2.5 Technical support for charcoal briquetting producers enhanced

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
(2.1) 60 sustainable charcoal cooperatives organized and operational with 2,400 charcoal champions in pilot districts. Activities to meet this KPI will involve:
Developing ranking criteria for categorizing charcoal producers or entrepreneurs
Conducting surveys to rank different actors into pre-determined categories
Training of all groups on local ordinances and standards for sustainable charcoal certification schemes as well as improved kiln technologies
Demonstration of Casamance kiln operation and viability to target group (total of 400 casamance kilns deployed)
Demonstration of retort kiln operation and viability to target groups (total of 200 retort kilns deployed)
MRV, tracking and licensing system established for all improved kilns piloted
All groups in compliance with certification standards (as per Output 1.4.1)
(2.2) Delivery model to support consumer financing schemes for charcoal producing groups with local financial institutions established.
(2.3) Basic Project submitted for registration to appropriate authority under an appropriate carbon development methodology in the Voluntary Market and/or a Sustainable Charcoal NAMA Design Document developed and endorsed
(2.4) Profit margin per output unit of charcoal produced with new technologies increased by at least 20% per group (with new kilns) as compared to baseline scenario for all participating charcoal cooperatives
(2.5) Training and technical assistance provided to all briquetting businesses that are receiving loans from Micro-Finance Institutions in conjunction with CleanStart

baseline.comment:
(2.1) BAU Carbonization Technologies = Earthmound Kilns @ 10% efficiency conversion
(2.1) Biomass Sources = non-renewable
(2.1) No widespread use of improved kiln technologies and those that are in use are not licensed or monitored
(2.1) Charcoal producers in target districts are not formally organized and do not have access to improved carbonization technologies
(2.2) No recognized charcoal production SMEs in target areas
(2.2) No organized charcoal producer organizations
(2.3) No carbon finance projects in Uganda dealing with sustainable charcoal have been registered with a carbon authority
(2.3) No charcoal NAMA Design Document developed or submitted
(2.4) Average income of a typical itinerant charcoal producer in target districts established as baseline during year 1
(2.5) CleanStart scoping mission documented that at present there are about 17 formal briquette makers in Uganda, receiving limited training and financial assistance
(2.5) A detailed baseline will be done as part of the CleanStart operations

target.comment:
(2.1) 143,314 metric tons of wood saved over project lifetime from improved kilns compared to BAU scenario (14,431 hectares of avoided deforestation)
(2.1) Lifetime energy savings (compared to BAU scenario) of 1,843,200,000 MJ for Casamance kilns (avoided emissions of 210,816 tCO2eq) ; and
(2.1) 9,737,142,857 MJ for retort kilns (avoided emissions of 1,113,686 tCO2eq)
(2.1) additional lifetime avoided methane emissions for all retort kilns introduced of 252,000 tCO2 eq
(2.2) 60 charcoal producer associations with over 2400 members established and registered (15 in each district) and operating sustainable charcoal businesses by end of project
(2.2) Consumer financing schemes available for registered charcoal producing (CPA) associations by end of project. By end of project 20% of the registered CPA qualify for credit facilities from local financial institutions
(2.3) Carbon Project successfully registered for carbon financing under Voluntary Carbon Standards by end of year 3.
(2.3) NAMA Design Document developed and endorsed by end of year 3
(2.4) At least 5 CPAs in each district supply charcoal directly to large wholesalers in urban areas
(2.5) The CleanStart business plan noted that the opportunity exists for the number of briquette producers to increase to at least 50 and daily production can easily be raised 8 tons to 50 tons per day. If confirmed the target would then be to provide training and TA to at least 50 charcoal briquetting enterprises by the end of the project
(2.5) A detailed baseline will be done as part of the CleanStart start-up and call for proposals with FSPs
(2.5) Emission reductions from TA for the briquetting enterprises will be developed once its confirmed whether the relevant FSPs will indeed provide loans for the improved machines

actual.comment:
(2.1) ,(2.2), (2.3), (2.4) are not yet done, they are planned to commence in year two of the project because they await establishment of the realistic baseline through the national charcoal survey and establishment of the database that will be used to study the trends.
(2.5) As part of enhancing the technical capacity for briquette businesses within the 4 districts, 16 briquette producing groups were identified, sensitized and introduced to improved methods of briquette production and marketing for increased output and income for the group members. Over 30% of the groups are entirely women groups.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description:
Outcome 3.1 Strengthening the capacity of key stakeholders in SFM and SLM best practices and establishment of sustainable woodlots
Outcome 3.2 SLM/SFM knowledge effectively transferred from ongoing SLM Best Practices in the neighboring Cattle Corridor districts replicated in the four target districts

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
(3.1) Improved capacities of stakeholders in targeted districts to manage SFM and establish dedicated renewable biomass feed stocks. More specifically:
- At least 1,100 private woodlot owners in the four pilot districts identified, trained and contracted to make land available for woodlot establishment (minimum 5,900 hectares set-aside).
- Training all communities/woodlot managers on new charcoal regulations and SFM best practices, including use of specified tree species and optimal ecological yield from such species.
-Technical support provided to all woodlot owners on tree nursery management as an entrepreneurial activity with target to plant over 17.4 million seedlings
- Dissemination of over 17.4 million tree seedlings to woodlot owners
- Establishment of land use and forest management plans (including zoning and mapping of forest areas) for all targeted woodlot areas
- Contracts signed between woodlots owners and charcoal producer groups for feedstock supply
(3.2) SLM/SFM knowledge effectively transferred from ongoing SLM projects in neighboring districts to four pilot districts for this project.

baseline.comment:
(3.1) No community or private woodlots for charcoal production in targeted districts
(3.1) Degraded forests and agricultural land in the four districts
(3.2)
* Limited amount of land in targeted districts under SFM regimes or benefiting from SFM practices (baseline to be established during year 1)
* 4,800 ha of land across four districts deforested each year for charcoal production
* Conservation farming not widely practiced across target districts
* Communities in targeted districts have not had exposure to the SCISLM approach or LADA tool
* District Land Use Planning staff have little knowledge of techniques that support community planning, implementation processes and land degradation assessment
* No detailed mapping of biomass stocks (both forestry and agricultural areas) done in targeted districts
* No method in place to accurately measure and monitor land use change and deforestation in targeted districts

target.comment:
(3.1)
- Accumulated yields of 368,770 MT of renewable biomass produced over 5,900 hectares under woodlot management by end of project (year 5) and 1,475,083 MT of biomass accumulation over the lifetime.
- Net avoided lifetime emission reductions of 2,699,402 tCO2 of avoided deforestation compared to the BAU scenario from use of this renewable biomass in kilns compared to a BAU scenario
(3.2)
- 50,000 ha of forestlands across four pilot districts brought under improved multifunctional forest management leading to enhanced carbon sequestartion of 2,100,000 tCO2eq over lifetime
- A least half of land under improved SFM registers reduction in land degradation by at least 20% as measured by reduction in soil erosion and improvement in soil organic matter
- Conservation farming practices piloted leading to verified improved soil organic matter and yield increasesd across 400 hectares
- Communitys indigenous knowledge of SLM enhanced using the Stimulating Community Innovations (SCISLM) approach to generate local solutions to land degradation
- Land use planning (one each target district) done using FAO-LADA-WOCAT developed.
- District Land Use Planning staff trained in the use of techniques that support community planning, implementation processes and land degradation assessment
- Mapping completed of all targeted areas under sustainable forestry management as well as agricultural lands under SLM in collaboration with FAO and National Forestry Authoritys new GIS/mapping platform

actual.comment:
(3.1) In the process of improving capacities of stakeholders in targeted districts, about 500 members (close to 20% women) from different communities in the 4 districts were identified, registered, trained in Sustainable Forest Management practices and supported to plant 600,000 trees for sustainable woodlots. This could translate to about 300 ha of new woodlot for sustainable feed stock established by beneficiaries in 4 districts
(3.2) As a strategy for improving management of Central Forest Reserves to enhance carbon sequestration form local forest reserves, close to 10,000 ha of Degraded Central Forest Reserves in the 4 districts were identified and final plans their restoration and enrichment planting completed.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the weather, climate and hydrological monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to extreme weather and planning adaptation to climate change in Uganda.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard (see Annex 7).
2. Domestic finance committed to DoM, DWRM and other relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change.

baseline.comment:
1. Average capacity scorecard rating of 77 across men and women (Annex 7).
2. Annual budget of US$1,500,000 and $ 450,000 allocated to DoM and DWRM respectively to monitor extreme weather and climate change.

target.comment:
1. CCA capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 143 for both men and women (Annex 7).
2. 20% increase in domestic financing committed to DoM, DWRM and other relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change (including equipment operation and maintenance).

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced capacity of the DoM and DWRM to monitor and forecast extreme weather, hydrology and climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. % of national coverage of climate/weather and hydrological infrastructure.
2. Frequency and timeliness of climate-related data availability.

baseline.comment:
1.UNMA (DoM) 10% national coverage of operational manual (9 %) and automatic (1%) weather stations (synoptic, agro/hydro-meteorological) (Annex 8).
1.DWRM 28% national coverage of operational surface hydrometric stations (24%) and automatic weather stations (4%) (Annex 8).
1.Number and Type (operational stations):
Automatic weather stations: 6
Manual synoptic, agro/hydro-meteorological stations: 12
Surface hydrometric stations: 35
Automatic water level stations: 0
2. UNMA (DoM) Hourly for synoptic stations. Once a month for agro- and hydro-meteorological stations.
Seasonal forecasts have a lead-time of 0-2 weeks.
Monthly weather reviews and forecasts are not issued at present.
Agro-met monthly advisories are not issued at present.
2. DWRM weekly to monthly.

target.comment:
1. DoM 47% national coverage of operational manual (26%) and automatic (33%) weather stations (synoptic, agro-/hydro-meteorological) (Annex 8).
1.DWRM 50% national coverage of operational surface hydrometric stations (50%) and automatic weather and water level stations (19%) (Annex 8).
1.Number and Type (operation stations)
Automatic weather stations: 36
Manual synoptic, agro/hydro-meteorological stations: 44
Surface hydrometric stations: 75
Automatic water level stations: 16
2. UNMA (DoM) Hourly for synoptic stations and dekadal (every ten days) for agro- and hydro-meteorological stations.
Seasonal forecasts have a lead time of 2 weeks.
A monthly weather review and forecasts are issued.
A monthly agro-met advisory is issued.
2. DWRM 6 hourly; and 2-4 hourly for flood prone sub-regions.

actual.comment: There is not much change on this target as the equipment is in the process of procurement.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Efficient and effective use of hydro-meteorological and environmental information for making early warnings and long-term development plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. % of population with access to improved climate information and drought, flood and severe storm warnings (disaggregated by gender).
2. Sector-specific policies, annual budgets and development plans that integrate climate information (type and level of development plans).

baseline.comment:
1.0. 3% of men and 3% women with access to improved climate information and flood, drought and severe weather warnings (to be confirmed during project inception).
Male: 920,000
Female: 1,010,000
2. 0

target.comment:
1. 12% of men and 12% women with access to improved climate information and flood, drought and severe weather warnings(to be confirmed during project inception).
Male: 3,300,000
Female: 3,700,000
2. 3 sector specific policies (including the National Policy for Disaster Preparedness and Management), investment plans and annual budgets and 10 district development plans.

actual.comment: A lot of preparatory activities have been implemented towards these outputs, notably consultancies and partnerships outlined in the project implementation section: Cost Benefit and Market Analysis; M&E Consultancy; IT Specialist to assess synoptic stations and recommend suitable equipment for connectivity to the AWSs; Consultancy on Protocol and Agreements on data sharing; Hydromet-AWLS.
